beans.description:
This adaptor does the following...
* reads xml from file * validates the xml (traps errors and forwards them to stdout) * language sensitively adds an 'opinion' attribute to each book in the box using the 'title' contents if available * writes to stdout
It's intended to show you how to use Ruby scripting and manipulate XML. The validation is not strictly necessary but useful for this example.
Run it like this...
java -Djruby.home=${RUBY_HOME} org.openadaptor.spring.SpringAdaptor -config ruby-xpath.xml
You need the following in your classpath
jruby/lib/jruby-engine.jar jruby/lib/jruby.jar lib lib/openadaptor.jar lib/openadaptor-spring.jar lib/openadaptor-depends.jar
The ruby-engine provides JSR223 scripting integration.
Once it is running it will read input from the configured file (input/inputboxes.xml) and it will insert a book review opinion for each book in each box.
This example builds upon javascript-xpath.xml, as when using ruby we have much richer XML support and can handle things like multiple nested elements of the same type.
The example shows how "oa_data" is automatically bound to the incoming/outgoing record, and can be read/assigned from within the ruby script. We also demonstrate creating additional bindings from bean properties to ruby variables (using "lang" as an example) including how to detect when no setting for this variable has been injected into the ruby script.
The same work is done by groovy-xpath.xml, ruby-xpath.xml and jython-xpath.xml. The implementations each use DOM/XPath libraries available in their standard distributions, and so their performance is dependent both on the speed of the scripting runtime and of those libraries. So direct comparisons over their speed is not representative, but in this particular case groovy was significantly faster (jython was a bit faster than ruby but the ruby code used is much cleaner than the jython code used). We've left the metrics in for you to see for yourself -- note that there is a significant set up overhead when using scripting so you will want to push through hundreds or thousands of boxes to get representative timings (rather than the single box in the example file) and you will also want to redirect stdout to file.

bean.description: Read entire contents of input file
This processor validates the data as an xml string. Ensure that the xml has book as root.
Add an opinion including the title if present.

property.name: additionalBindings
property.description: Data objects to bind to Ruby variables (demonstrates parameterising script).

property.name: script
property.value:
# XML parse the input string: require 'rexml/document' include REXML doc = Document.new($oa_data)
# Default the reviewing language (if not bound to a value by a bean property definition): $lang = 'en_gb' if not $lang
# Update the parsed XML model by iterating over the book elements: doc.each_element("//book") { |book| # Make sure there is an opinion element in our chosen language: opinion = book.elements["opinion[@lang='#{$lang}']"] if not opinion opinion = book.add_element("opinion", {"lang" => $lang}) end
# Find out the most appropriate title given our chosen language: bookTitle = book.elements["title[@lang='#{$lang}']"] if not bookTitle bookTitle = book.elements["title[@lang='en_us']"] if not bookTitle bookTitle = book.elements["title"] end end
# Update the text body of the opinion element in our chosen language: if not bookTitle opinion.text = "Can\'t tell you what this book is called but it is indeed a fine book" else opinion.text = bookTitle[0].value + " is indeed a fine book" end }
# Write the updated XML model out as a string (did not work when I tried to write direct # to $oa_data and in any case doc.write() appends so we need to set it to empty string): result = "" doc.write(result, indent=2) $oa_data = result
